document.docTitle: Ptychidia erynella Harzhauser & Landau 2019, new sp.
document.masterDocTitle: Turritellidae (Gastropoda) of the Miocene Paratethys Sea with considerations about turritellid genera

subSubSection.paragraph:
non
Turritella ( Haustator ) eryna rotundata Schaffer, 1912
—
Steininger et al ., 1973: 398
, pl. 3, figs 7a–c [probably an
Archimediella
]. non
Turritella ( Haustator ) eryna turriformis Voorthuysen, 1944
— Švagrovský, 1982: 14 , pl. 4, fig. 2.

Types.
Holotype NHMW 1963/0522/0000 ( Fig. 18F ), SL: 41.8 mm , 10.4 MD: mm, Guntersdorf ( Austria ), illustrated in Sieber (1960 , pl. 1, fig. 10) as
Turritella
(
Haustator
) eryna eryna d’Orbigny .
Paratypes NHMW 1861/0034/0032 ( Fig. 18E ), SL: 55.1 mm , MD: 13.7 mm , Kalladorf ( Austria )
; NHMW 2018/0279/0002 ( Figs 18G
1 –G
2
), SL: 56.2 mm , MD: 12.2 mm , Guntersdorf ( Austria ); NHMW 2019/00277/0003 ( Fig. 18H ), SL: 58.3 mm , MD: 13.9 mm , Guntersdorf ( Austria ); NHMW 2018/0277/0002, ( Fig. 18N ), SL: 19.9 mm , MD: 5.1 mm , Grund ( Austria ).

Additional illustrated material. Fig. 18J : NHMW 1963/0521/0000, SL: 45.1 mm , MD: 13.4 mm , Grund ( Austria ), illustrated in Sieber (1960 , pl. 1, fig. 5) as
Turritella ( Haustator ) eryna turriformis van Voorthuysen
; Fig. 18K : NHMW 1963/0520/0000, SL: 44.0 mm, MD: 12.8 mm , Grund ( Austria ), illustrated as
Turritella ( Haustator ) eryna communiformis Voorth. in Sieber (1960
, pl. 1, figs 6–7); Figs 18M : NHMW 1963/0543/0000, SL: 43.6 mm , MD: 12.7 mm , Immendorf ( Austria ), illustrated as
Turritella ( Haustator ) striatellata Sacco in Sieber (1960
, pl. 1, fig. 19).

Type stratum.
Silty sand of the Grund Formation (
Zuschin et al. 2004
).

Etymology. Referring to
Turritella eryna d’Orbigny, 1852
, with which the species was frequently confused.

Studied material. 1 spec. NHMW 1861/0034/0032, 3 spec. NHMW 1869/0003/0068, Kalladorf ( Austria ); 1 spec. NHMW 2018/0277/0003, 50 spec. NHMW 2018/0277/0004, 1 spec. NHMW 2018/0277/0001, 1 spec. NHMW 2018/0277/0002, 1 spec. NHMW 1963/0521/0000, Grund ( Austria ), illustrated in Sieber (1960 , pl. 1, fig. 5) as
Turritella ( Haustator ) eryna turriformis van Voorthuysen
, 1 spec. NHMW 1963/0520/0000, illustrated in Sieber (1960 , pl. 1, figs 6–7) as
Turritella ( Haustator ) eryna communiformis van Voorthuysen
, 1 spec. NHMW 1963/0524/0000, illustrated in Sieber (1960 , pl. 1, fig. 13) as
Turritella ( Haustator ) eryna eryna d’Orbigny
, 2 spec. NHMW 1989/0032/0001, 2 spec. NHMW 1989/0033/0001, Grund ( Austria ); 8 spec. NHMW 2018/0279/0001, 1 spec. NHMW 2018/0277/0002, Guntersdorf ( Austria ); 1 spec. NHMW 1963/0522/0000, Guntersdorf ( Austria ), illustrated in Sieber (1960 , pl. 1, fig. 10) as
Turritella ( Haustator ) eryna eryna d’Orbigny
; 20 spec. NHMW 2018/0280/0001, Nodendorf ( Austria ); 7 spec. NHMW1861/0050/0056, Karnabrunn ( Austria ); 1 spec. NHMW 1860/0050/0114, Laa ( Austria ); 7 spec. NHMW 1863/0015/0993, Hrušovany nad Jevišovkou ( Czech Republic ); 16 spec. 1845/0031/0053, 1 spec. NHMW 1872/0020/0213, 1 spec. NHMW 1963/0517/0000, Wirtatobel at Bregenz ( Austria ), illustrated in Sieber (1960 , pl. 1, fig. 26) as
Turritella turris Basterot
; 2 spec. NHMW 1872/0020/0196, Kaltenbachgraben ( Germany ); Ermingen ( Germany ), 1 spec. NHMW1963/0527/0000, Immendorf ( Austria ), illustrated as
Turritella badensis tricarinata Handmann, 1882
, in Sieber (1960 , pl. 1, fig. 18);

Description. Shell medium-sized, slender, of about 18 teleoconch whorls. Protoconch unknown. Early teleoconch whorls high, angulated at mid-whorl with deep suture. Onset of primaries not preserved; angulation coinciding with B spiral cord adjoined by weaker C spiral cord and faint A spiral cord (not always visible) starting at least on 3 rd to 4 th teleoconch whorls. Height of whorls successively decreasing¸ angulation shifting slightly below mid-whorl on neanic whorls. B spiral cord most prominent, ranging from keel-like to convex. C spiral cord shifting down, close to suture, resulting in broad, convex interspace between B and C spiral cords. Sutural ramp flat to weakly convex with distinct A spiral cord, often accompanied by r cord and one or two tertiary spiral cords. Secondary spiral cord between B and C spiral cords, rarely equaling primaries; no additional secondary cords below C spiral cord aside from peribasal cord of variable strength. Lateral sinus simple, steep, maximum depth below mid-whorl, adapical part moderately convex without inflection point, abapical part weakly convex, nearly straight. Aperture subquadratic, higher than broad; outer lip thin, inner lip narrowly reflected firming narrow umbilical chink. Parietal callus glossy, thin, indistinct, covering only small part of base. Basal sinus nearly straight. Base moderately convex with about eight narrow, usually poorly developed, secondary spiral cords. No inner lirae detected in Austrian and French specimens.

Shell measurements and ratios. n = 10 near complete specimens: SL: μ = 53.9 mm (σ = 3.2 mm ), MD: μ = 12.7 mm (σ = 0.7 mm ), AA: μ = 17.9° (σ = 0.5°), PA: μ = 12.6° (σ = 1.0°). Lateral sinus (n = 8): LS angle = 28.6° (σ = 2.4°), LS p = 1.2 (σ = 0.1), LS d = 4.7 (σ = 1.0).

Discussion. Paratethyan occurrences of this species have been identified as
Turritella eryna d’Orbigny, 1952
, which was recorded by Cossmann & Peyrot (1922) from the early Miocene of the Aquitaine Basin.
Lozouet et al . (2001)
, however, considered
Turritella eryna d’Orbigny, 1852
and
Turritella subtriplicata d’Orbigny, 1852
as synonyms of
Turritella turris de Basterot, 1825
. No middle Miocene occurrences have been reported by Cossmann & Peyrot (1922) and
Lozouet et al. (2001)
for these species. Specimens from Léognan and Saucats in France , stored in the NHMW collection and identified as
Turritella turris
, are indeed similar to Paratethyan specimens in overall shape, but differ in their strongly keeled early neanic whorls. Unlike
P. vindobonensis
, the initial part of the protoconch of
T. turris
is depressed and a distinct A spiral cord appears on the first teleoconch whorl [see
Fig. 18I
: NHMW 1872/0020/0048, SL: 40.8 mm , MD: 12.0 mm, Léognan ( France )].

Sieber (1960) identified some specimens as
Turritella eryna communiformis van Voorthuysen, 1944
and T. e. turriformis van Voorthuysen, 1944 , which were originally described from the Hemmoorian (late Burdigalian to early Langhian) to Langenfeldian (Serravallian and early Tortonian) of the North Sea (van Voorthuysen 1944 ). The neanic whorls of the specimens illustrated by van Voorthuysen (1944) are less angulated and differ from the Paratethyan species in their prominent spiral cords on the sutural ramp and the generally broader apical angle, regularly convex whorls and more uniform spiral sculpture.
Ptychidia erynella
is highly reminiscent of
P. vindobonensis
in sculpture and whorl profile. In both species ‘
carinata
’ and ‘
plana
’ morphs have been described.
Ptychidia vindobonensis
, however, is generally larger (about 10 mm at same growth stage) and less slender. Inner lirae are frequent in
P. vindobonensis
but virtually absent in all investigated
P. erynella
. Moreover,
P. erynella
seems to be restricted to the North Alpine-Carpathian Foreland Basin, where it appears in enormous numbers. It is absent from middle Badenian faunas in the Vienna Basin, where
P. vindobonensis
predominates in numbers.

In most shells, the B spiral cord coincides with a more or less distinct angulation below mid-whorl. The variability of sculpture results mainly from the strength and presence of the secondary and tertiary spiral cords. In some morphotypes, all spiral cords attain similar strengths and were treated as subspecies communiformis van
Voorthuysen, 1944
in the literature, whereas specimens with prominent primaries were identified as subspecies turriformis van Voorthuysen, 1944 . Both morphotypes co-occur in the rich lower Badenian localities Grund, Immendorf and Guntersdorf in the North Alpine-Carpathian Foreland Basin, including transitional morphs. Some of these morphotypes are close to the specimens from the Ottnangian (early Miocene) of Ermingen ( Germany ), where this turritellid forms a mass-occurrence known as ‘Erminger Turritellenplatte’ ( Baier 2008 ; Höltke 2009 ). The preservation of these specimens is rather poor, and the species may be closer to P. ?
turris
than to
P. erynella
.

(see Fig. 18L : NHMW 1845/00031/0053, SL: 45.9, MD: 13.7 mm , Ermingen ( Germany ). Sieber (1960) and Stürmer (1989) identified a pathological specimen from Immendorf ( Austria ) as
Turritella ( Haustator ) striatellata Sacco, 1895
( Fig. 18M ). The early teleoconch whorls of this specimen do not differ from other specimens of
P. erynella
from the same locality and the subsequent loss of spiral sculpture is caused by severe shell damage at an early stage of growth.
